title: Giving and Receiving Love
intro: A gentle breathing meditation using a ball of light — receiving love on the inhale, offering it on the exhale.
body:
Hi.

Take a moment to arrive.
Let your shoulders loosen. Let your jaw soften.
And if it feels okay, allow your breathing to become a little slower — not forced, just gently guided.

Imagine, as you breathe in, that a small ball of warm light begins to form inside you.
Not a spotlight. Not something blinding.
Just a soft glow — steady, kind, and calm.

As you inhale, the light gathers.
As you exhale, it stays with you.
You don’t have to do it perfectly.
Just imagine the light responding to your breath.

Now, bring to mind someone you care about.
Someone who feels safe to love.
It could be a partner, a friend, a family member, a pet.
Or someone who has supported you in a quiet way.

On your next inhale, let the ball of light grow a little brighter.
Let it collect warmth.
Let it gather tenderness.

And as you exhale, imagine offering that light to this person.
Not as a sacrifice.
Not as something you lose.
But as something you can share.
A gentle gift.
A kind sending.

Inhale… the light gathers in you.
Exhale… the light moves toward them.

You might imagine it traveling as a soft stream.
Or leaving your chest like a warm breath.
Or drifting like a lantern through the air.
However it appears is okay.

Take a few breaths like this.
Inhale — receive love.
Exhale — offer love.

Now, if you feel ready, bring to mind someone neutral.
Someone you see in passing.
A cashier, a neighbor, a stranger on the street.
Someone whose life you don’t know.

Inhale — let the light gather.
Exhale — offer it toward them.
Not because you owe them anything.
But because kindness can be practice.
Because love can be widened.

Now, gently, only if it feels safe… bring to mind someone difficult.
This is not about excusing harm.
It’s not about pretending.
It’s not about forcing forgiveness.

This is about freeing your own heart from constant tension.
About loosening the grip that pain can have.

Choose someone who feels difficult in a manageable way.
Not the most painful person, if that feels too much.
Just someone your mind tightens around.

Notice what happens in your body.
Maybe a clench. A heat. A heaviness.
That’s okay.
You don’t have to push it away.

Now inhale — and gather the light.
Not bright. Not dramatic.
Just steady.
A small, quiet glow.

And as you exhale, offer the light anyway.
Not to say “what happened was fine.”
But to say:
“May you be held by life.
May you be softened.
May you be healed in whatever way you need.
And may I be free.”

Inhale — light gathers.
Exhale — light releases.

If resistance rises, that’s normal.
You can return to a safer person.
Or you can offer the light to yourself instead.
Because you are part of this practice too.

So now, bring the light back home.
Inhale — let the glow fill your chest.
Exhale — let it spread through your shoulders, your belly, your hands.

If it helps, place a hand over your heart.
And offer the light to yourself.

Inhale — receiving.
Exhale — giving.

You don’t have to get it right.
You only have to be willing.

When you’re ready, let the image of the light become softer.
Let your breath return to its natural rhythm.

And before you go, take one last gentle inhale.
And one last gentle exhale.

Thank you for taking this moment.
You can come back to this practice whenever you need.
